sentences.sentence: As we Canadians watch the endless stream of American news about race and racism we may smugly think we have escaped the worst of it.

Yet Black-Canadians, ethnic and religious minorities and our Indigenous people can attest to the daily reality of racism, ranging from outright discrimination to micro-aggressions in our streets, schools and workplaces.Despite research, including the Centre for International Governance Innovation's Diversity Dividend report, that shows ethnocultural diversity is a financial benefit to workplaces in terms of both productivity and revenue, we are moving only very slowly in making the changes necessary to capitalize on untapped human capital in our society and workplaces.
We often assume that we hire the most talented individuals regardless of race, creed or gender.

But this is not happening.Academic colleagues from the University of Toronto have shown that Anglo-Saxon-sounding names were 35 per cent more likely to get a call back than applicants presumed to be Indian or Chinese.
This was tested through a simulation using the exact same resumes, but with different names.

Imagine members of our ethnocultural communities who have the same academic credentials and work experience on paper, but who, when they submit their resumes, are still discriminated against one out of three times because of their name and, implicitly, the colour of their skin.

Although this is not a uniquely Canadian problem, here is another blight: similar studies were done in the United States and Germany but Canadian workplace discrimination was found to be much higher.This is the same Canada that opened its hearts and doors to Syrian refugees and became a world model for how to make empathy a collective mission.
Federal and provincial governments have invested billions in bridging programs, settlement services and language training.

But none of that can help targeted individuals who are not given a chance because they have an ethnic-sounding name or live in a particular neighbourhood.Whether it is unconscious bias, misguided stereotypes or outright discrimination, we have a problem.
We need an innovation in hiring practices to level the playing field and ensure that the most qualified individual gets the position he or she deserves.
As we come out of COVID-19 lockdowns to restart the economy and our businesses, there is lots of talk about coming back even stronger and more resilient - but to also do things differently.
Moreover, many workplaces have been forced to implement digital transformations of their operations and business activities.
Human resources (HR) needs its transformation, too.

To that end, we recommend blind recruitment.HR departments that use blind recruitment require applicants to apply through online sites that automatically remove their names from applications and also scrub out other signifiers of race, gender or ethnicity.
Used by major companies like Deloitte, BBC, HSBC, Google, Virgin Money and KPMG, blind recruitment allows firms to get a diverse pool of candidates to the interview phase of a hiring process.
Other companies have added online quizzes to test short-listed candidates' skills and suitability for positions that removes potential biases on schooling and education.

Technology can even scrub reference letters of words and phrases that may also prompt discrimination.A young woman looks over her resume while waiting for a job interview during a youth employment fair in 2019.To optimize diverse outcomes, interviews need to be conducted using diverse HR professionals who have undergone training against unconscious bias.
Of course, this is far easier to do in large companies.
But the technology is getting better and more affordable.
Canadian businesses can lead the way and take advantage of sophisticated technology to facilitate this move to a better and more equitable workplace.Blind recruitment is not a panacea, of course.
Even if a workplace can successfully recruit diverse candidates, discrimination can continue if an organization does not work on inclusivity.

An inclusive company requires leaders to demonstrate their commitment to achieving diversity and inclusion, tracking and measuring where there is room to improve in diverse hiring and retention, and promoting an open culture that values diversity in all its forms.
Ensuring there is pay equity also needs to be monitored and addressed.
Blind recruitment cannot address an organizational culture or a fragmented society that breeds or allows discrimination, nor, obviously, can it stop world leaders from tweeting hateful things.
But blind recruitment is a small start.

It is 2020 and there is no room for complacency or smugness.National PostBessma Momani is a full professor of political science at the University of Waterloo and Nada Basir an assistant professor at Waterloo's Conrad School of Entrepreneurship and Business.Wayne K.
